direction.raw_text: Epic beauty: cobalt mountains beneath a glowering purple sky fringed with pink, as if the clouds were a lid too small for the earth; a cascading landscape of boulders shrouded in deep green grass; and the blue lochs, reflecting the sky. We hear a voice, husky, Scottish...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I will tell you of William Wallace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A farmhouse and a large barn lie nestled in a Scottish valley. Riding down the roads that lead in from opposite sides are Scottish noblemen in full regalia: eye-popping tartans, sparkling chestplates. Even the horses are draped in scarlet. Behind each nobleman rides a single page boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another noble rides in from the opposite side. Two more appear down the road, converging on the barn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The nobles eye each other cautiously, but the truce holds. They enter the barn, with their pages...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Historians from England will say I am a liar. But history is written by those who have hung heroes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The King of Scotland had died without a son, and the king of England, a cruel pagan known as Edward the Longshanks, claimed the throne for himself. Scotlands nobles fought him, and fought each other, over the crown. So Longshanks invited them to talks of truce. No weapons, one page only.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Nestled in emerald hills are the thatched roof house and barn and outbuildings of a well-run farm. The farmer, MALCOLM WALLACE, and his nineteen-year-old son JOHN, both strong, tough men, are riding away from the farm. They hear hooves behind them and turn to see a boy riding after them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We FAVOR JOHN WALLACE, the nineteen-year-old sitting easily on his horse, beside his father...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Among the farmers of that shire was Malcolm Wallace, a commoner, with his own lands and two sons: John...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...and William.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: a skinny eight-year-old riding bareback, catches up to his father and older brother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They ride on, over the lush hills.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Told ya to stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I finished my chores. Where we goin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: MacAndrews'. He was supposed to visit when the truce was over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The horses are all gone; the place looks deserted. UP ON THE HILL we see the three Wallaces, looking down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He means William. He and his elder son spur their horses.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stay here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Wallaces ride up, looking around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Malcolm finds a pitchfork, John the woodpile axe...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: MacAndrews!... MacAndrews!?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE BARN POV from within as the door opens and a widening block of sunlight illuminates the dusty shadows. Malcolm and John Wallace step in, and are shocked to see...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THE WALLACES Hanging from the rafters of the barn are thirty Scottish noblemen and thirty pages, their faces purple and contorted by the strangulation hanging, their tongues protruding. Malcolm stabs the pitchfork into the ground in useless anger; John still grips the axe as he follows his father through the hanging bodies of the noblemen to the back row, to see the one man in commoner's dress, like theirs...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: MacAndrews.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ; John spins; William has entered the back door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before his father and brother can think of anything to say, William, with a boy's curiosity, touches the spurred foot of the hanged noblemen we first saw riding in. It's too solid; he takes a real look at the face, and suddenly -- WILLIAM R -- real!!!... Ahhhhhgggg!... He turns to run, but knocks back into the feet of the hanged man behind him! In blind panic he darts in another direction, and runs into another corpse, and another; the hanged men begin to swing, making it harder for William's father and older brother to fight their way to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then, worst of all, William sees the pages, boys like himself, hanged in a row behind their masters! Finally his father and brother reach William and hug him tight. There in the barn, among the swinging bodies of the hanged nobles, Malcolm Wallace grips his sons.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: William! Get out of here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why would MacAndrews make so many scarecrows?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: William! William!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Murderin' English bastards.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The cottage looks peaceful, the windows glowing yellow into the night. From outside the house we see John rise and close the shutters of the kitchen, where men are gathered. We PAN UP to the upper bedroom window...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Young William is in nightmarish sleep. He mumbles in smothered terror; he twitches. We see
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the blue-grays of his dream, William stands at the door of the barn, gazing at the hanged knights. We WHIP PAN to their faces, garish, horrible... Then one of the heads moves and its eyes open! William wants to run, but he can't get his body to respond... and the hanging nobleman, his bloated tongue still bursting through his lips, moans...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Will--iam...!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: tears himself from sleep; looking around, swallowing back his tears and panic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A dozen strong, tough farmers have huddled. Red-headed CAMPBELL, scarred and missing fingers, is stirred up, while his friend MacCLANNOUGH is reluctant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Young Wallace has snuck down and is eavesdropping from the stairs. He sees his father drip his finger into a jug of whiskey and use the wet finger to draw on the tabletop.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wallace is right! We fight 'em!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Every nobleman who had any will to fight was at that meeting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So it's up to us! We show them we won't lie down to be their slaves!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We can't beat an army, not with the fifty farmers we can raise!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We don't have to beat 'em, just fight 'em. To show 'em we're not dogs, but men.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They have a camp here. We attack them at sunset tomorrow. Give us all night to run home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Malcolm and John have saddled horses; they are checking the short swords they've tucked into grain sacks when William comes out of the barn with his own horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These words from his youngest son make Malcolm pause, and kneel, to look into William's eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Malcolm and John mount their horses and ride away, leaving William looking forlorn. They wave; he waves back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: William, you're staying here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can fight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aye. But it's our wits that make us men. I love ya, boy. You stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: EXT SCOTTISH HILLS, NEAR THE WALLACE FARM

direction.raw_text: It's strangely quiet, until William and his friend HAMISH CAMPBELL, a red-headed like his father, race up the hillside and duck in among a grove of trees. Breathless, gasping, they press their backs to the tree bark. William peers around a tree, then shrinks back and whispers...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hamish leans forward for a look, but William pulls him back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They wait; heavy FOOTSTEPS. Then from around the edge of the grove three enormous, ugly hogs appear. The boys hurling rotten eggs. The eggs slap the snouts of the pigs, who scatter as the boys charge, howling. We PULL BACK... as the sun goes down on their play.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They're coming!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How many?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Three, maybe more!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Armed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're English soldiers, ain't they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With your father and brother gone, they'll kill us and burn the farm!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's up to us, Hamish!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not yet! Here he comes, be ready!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The boys walk toward the house, beneath a lavender sky.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wanna stay with me tonight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wanna have supper waitin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll get those English pigs tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aye, we'll get 'em.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: William's face appears at the window, looking toward
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of trees and heather, where there is no sign of life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William has cooked stew in a pot, and now spoons up two steaming bowls full and sets them out on the table. But he is only hoping. He looks out the window again; he is still all alone. So he leaves a candle burning on the table beside the stew, and moves up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The house is silent, fog rolling around it in the dawn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William has been awake all night, afraid to sleep. He rises, and in QUICK CUTS: he dresses; he moves down the hall, stops at the door of his father's bedroom and sees the undisturbed bed. He moves on, passing the door of his brother's room, also unrumpled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He finds the two cold bowls of stew, beside the exhausted candle. He spoons up his own cold porridge, and eats alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William is in the barn loft, shoveling corn down to feed the hogs, while he glimpses something coming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An ox cart is coming down the curving lane. Its driver is Campbell, with MacClannough walking behind it. The farmers glance up at William, their faces grim... From his perch in the loft, William sees that the neighbors have brought: the bodies of his father and brother. The cart stops; Campbell, with a bandage around his left hand where more of his fingers are now missing, studies the back of the ox, as if it could tell him how to break such news. The butt of the ox seems to tell him to be matter-of-fact.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William looks away, he takes quick breaths, he looks back... but the bodies are still there.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: William... Come down here, lad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It's now surrounded by horses, wagons, and neighbors. The undertaker arrives in his hearse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On a table the undertaker has laid out the bodies and is preparing them. Cloths around the lower jaw and top of the head bind their mouths shut; pennies cover their eyes. Softly, William enters the shed, drawn to his father and brother. Campbell follows him in, wanting to stop him -- but what can he say now? The undertaker goes on with his work. William approaches the table; the bodies don't look real to him. He sees the wounds. The dried blood. The undertake pours water from a bowl and scrubs off the blood. But the wounds remain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on a grave, with a headstone marked ANNE WALLACE. We INCLUDE the two new graves freshly dug beside it, and see the mourners gathered before them. The sight of the boy, standing alone in front of the graves of his dead mother, as the bodies of his father and brother are lowered with ropes into the ground beside her, has all of the neighbors shaken. The local parish PRIEST drones mechanically in Latin. The farmers who were secretly gathered in Malcolm Wallace's kitchen the previous night are now glancing at William; but no one is anxious to adopt a grieving, a rebellious boy. Behind MacClannough are his wife and two daughters; his youngest is barely four, not half William's age; she's a beautiful girl with long auburn hair, and she clings to her own mother's hand, as if the open graves are the mouths of death and might suck her parents in too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With the final Amen, the neighbors drift from the graveside, pulling their Children along, to give William a last moment of private grief before the grave diggers cover the bodies. The boy stands alone over the open graves, his heart so shattered that he can scarcely cry; a single tear makes its way down his face. And the tiny girl feels for William in a way that the adults cannot. From the ground she pulls a Scottish thistle, moves to the softly weeping William and places the beautiful wild blossom in his hand. William looks up and their young eyes meet; her sad blue eyes hold William's as the grave diggers cover the bodies. Then a lone, mounted figure appears at the crest of the hill above them. Tall, thin and angular, in black clerical garb, he looks like the grim reaper. The girl hurries back to her mother's side; everyone watches in silence as the figure rides down to them. He is ARGYLE WALLACE. He looks like a human buzzard, his face craggy, permanently furious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Argyle glowers at the man, dismounts, and glares at William. William stares up at this frightening figure. They are interrupted by the ominous sound of approaching horses; a dozen mounted English soldiers, armed with lances, are approaching. Argyle rattles to the priest...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The soldiers ride right in among the mourners and stare down from their saddles, haughty, menacing, their LEADER brusque.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Outmaneuvered, the leader reins his horse away. Several of the farmers spit on the ground. Argyle glares at them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...Restare in pacem eternis, Amen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must be the relative of the deceased... William, this is your Uncle Argyle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were wise to hurry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Someone dead from this household?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We just had a funeral, isn't that what it means in England as well?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What it means in England -- and in Scotland too -- is that rebels have forfeited their lands. We were ambushed last night. But the Scots dragged their dead away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My brother and nephew perished two days ago, when their hay cart turned over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then we'll just have a peek at the wounds. (to his men) Dig 'em up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They've been sanctified and buried in the holy rites of God's church, and any hand that disturbs them now takes on eternal damnation. So please -- do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Funeral's over. Go home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: William and Argyle are sitting at the table, eating. Argyle has laid out a proper meal, with exact place settings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Argyle sits down and begins to dine with the boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Argyle pushes his food away; he has no appetite now.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Not that spoon, that one's for soup. Dip away from you. And don't slurp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll sleep here tonight. You'll come home with me. We'll let the house, and the lands too; plenty of willing neighbors.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to leave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't want your father to die either, did ya? But it happened.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did the priest say anything about the Resurrection? Or was it all about Judgment?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was in Latin, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Non loquis Latinum? You don't speak Latin? We have to fix that, won't we? (beat) Did he give the poetic benediction? The Lord bless thee and keep thee? Patris Benefactum et -- (beat) ...It was Malcolm's favorite.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Argyle knows nothing about tucking a boy in bed; he stands awkwardly idle as William scrubs his face at the washstand and crawls into bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Argyle grunts and starts out. Then he stops, turns back, leans down over William... and with great tenderness the grizzled old uncle kisses his nephew on his hair.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good night, Uncle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Argyle sits by the hearth, staring at the embers. He holds the huge broadsword that belonged to his brother. He looks at the handle, like a cross. He whispers...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tears of grief spill down the old man's cheeks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: "The Lord bless thee and keep thee..."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Once again the boy stands in the doorway of the barn, looking at the garish, hanged faces in his nightmare. Then a mangled hand comes from behind him and grasps his shoulder, William gasps, but the hand holds him gently. He turns to see his father, and his brother! They are wounded, bloody, but they smile at him; they're alive! Weeping in joy, William reaches to hug them, but his father stretches forth a forbidding hand. William keeps reaching out helplessly. His father and brother move past him to the hanged knights. Two empty nooses are there. Before the boy's weeping eyes they put their heads into the nooses, and hoist themselves up. William's grief explodes; his tears erupt and
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: tears flooding down his face. A dream! Still upset, still grieving, he gets up and goes looking for his uncle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William moves down to the room where his uncle would be sleeping. He opens the door. The bed has been slept in -- but his uncle is not there. He moves downstairs to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But his uncle is not there either. Then William hears a strange, haunting sound-distant, carried by the wind. He moves to the window and sees only moonlight. He opens the window and hears it more clearly: bagpipes. William lights a candle and throws open the door. Wind rushes in, blowing out his candle. But he hears the pipes, louder in the wind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William is barefoot and in only his nightshirt; but the sound of the pipes is growing louder. He moves through the moonlight, drawn toward -- the graveyard! He stops as he realizes this, then forces himself on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William moves to the top of the hill where his ancestors are buried, and discovers a haunting scene: two dozen men, the farmer/warriors of his neighborhood, are gathered in kilts -- and among them, a core of bagpipers. The pipes wail an ancient Scottish dirge, a tune of grief and redemption, a melody known to us as "Amazing Grace." Uncle Argyle has heard them and walked out too; he stands at the fringes of the torchlight, still holding the massive broadsword. He glances down, noticing William as the boy moves up beside him. William whispers...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The farmers file by the graveside, crossing themselves, each whispering his own private prayer. Argyle whispers, half to William, and half to himself...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William takes the sword from his uncle, and tries to lift it. Slowly, Argyle takes the sword back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He taps William on the temple with the tip of his finger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With an expert's easy fluidity, he lifts the huge sword. It glistens in the torchlight. The music plays, the notes hanging in the air, swirling in the Scottish breeze as if rising towards the stars...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What are they doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Saying goodbye in their own way -- in outlawed tartans, with outlawed pipes, playing outlawed tunes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your Daddy and I, we saw our own father buried like this, dead from fighting the English.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: First learn to use this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then I will teach you to use this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: William and his uncle ride off in a farm wagon. William has a bundle of clothes in his lap, and glances at his uncle as if afraid of his disapproval if he looks back. But he does glance back just once, to see the deserted farmhouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amid the scarlet and ermine robes of officiating lords, with gemstones sparkling everywhere, we hear...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Twelve years later, Longshanks supervised the wedding of his eldest son, also named Edward, who would succeed him to the throne.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: King of England, stands in the jeweled light of the ancient Abbey. Known as Longshanks because of the spindly legs that make him almost seven feet tall, he has a hawk's nose and a snake's eyes, punctuating a face of distinct cruelty. Historians of his day considered him and the line of Plantagenets from which he came to be devil worshipers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: As bride for his son, Longshanks had chosen a relative of his rival, the king of France.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: a nineteen-year-old virgin of stupendous beauty moves down the aisle, the light in her face outshining her blindingly white wedding gown. As she reaches the altar her hands tremble, but she maintains her poise and control. She looks toward EDWARD, Prince of Wales. Pampered young men surround him as his retinue. He takes her hand coldly and goes through the ceremony under his father's stare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The ceremony concluding, attendants lift back the bride's veil. Her wedding day, the ultimate moment -- and Prince Edward ignores her, to turn back to his friends. But prompted by one of the sour lords, he leans over and pecks his new Princess on the cheek. For an instant, we see in her eyes that her heart is dying. But she keeps her poise.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It was widely whispered that for the Princess to conceive, Longshanks would have to do the honors himself. That may have been what he had in mind all along.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Having seen to his obligations to provide for a successor, Longshanks set about his fondest business -- to crush Scotland, and turn his power against France...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Longshanks' narrow finger jabs Scotland.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are in the -- INT. ROYAL ENGLISH PALACE - DAY Longshanks is being listened to by his advisors, all in the outrageous splendor of royal military dress, and all deathly afraid of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He punches the map, then sees the Princess enter softly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Longshanks' eyes expand in fury; it is frightening to see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He spins back toward his generals. Ignored, the princess settles silently onto the cushions of the window seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One OLD ADVISOR speaks up hesitantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Longshanks glares at him, but takes the point. The wheels grind in his brain; his dark eyes falling on the Princess, he is inspired.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Scotland! Scot-land!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The French will grovel to anyone with strength! But how will they credit our strength when we cannot rule the whole of our own island?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where is my son?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your pardon, M'lord, he asked me to come in his stead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I sent for him -- and the little coward send you?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shall I leave, M'lord?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If he wants his queen to rule, then you stay and learn how! I will deal with him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobles are the key to the Scottish door. Grant their nobles land here in England. Give our own nobles estates in the north. Make them too greedy to oppose us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sire... Our nobles will be reluctant to relocate. New lands mean new taxes, and they are taxed already for our war in France.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps it's time to reinstitute an old custom. Grant them prima noctes, "First night." When any common girl inhabiting their lands is married, our lords shall have sexual rights to her on the night of her wedding. That should fetch just the kind of lords we want in Scotland.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The prince and a muscular young friend, PHILLIP, are stripped to the waist and fencing. They pay no attention to the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: or to the Princess as she enters. She watches them -- they are dancing more than fencing. Edward loses his sword; it clatters to the polished floor. He looks up at his wife, as if angry at her for having seen his clumsiness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Edward and his friend are fencing again, the clanging of their blunted swords so loud that she can't hear herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward loses his weapon again, and whirls on her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For an instant, anger flares into her eyes. She glances at Edward, and at the young man with him, then lowers her eyes and starts to back out. But Edward has noticed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stops, but does not raise her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lifts his hand and draws his friend Phillip to his side. Still the Princess does not lift her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She lifts her eyes. But she could not brace herself enough for what she sees: Edward nuzzling Phillip, the prince's bare chest to his muscular friend's bare back, both men glistening with sweat and sexual excitement. The Princess's eyes quiver... but she does not look away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts to leave, as quietly as she came. But her husband calls after her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She closes the door softly, on her husband and his lover.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is it?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You directed me to report to you the moment the king's conference was ended.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So I did! And what was so important about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Scotland. He intends --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He intends to grant --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shut up, would you! How can I concentrate?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...His majesty was quite keen that you should understand -- EDWARD All so very boring! He wants me to learn to fight too, so let me do it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you disapprove of Phillip?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (barely audible) No, M'lord.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at me. I said LOOK AT ME!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, my flower, do you understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. I had thought that... I was loathsome to you. Perhaps I am. If I may be excused, M'lord.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You may.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry, m'Lady, it is my royal responsibility to breed. And I assure you, when the time comes, I shall... manage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now in Edinburgh were gathered the council of Scottish nobles...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: COUNCIL - DAY The picturesque heart of Scotland, with its CASTLE on a fairy tale plateau above the Firth of Forth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The nobles are gathered around a huge table. They rise at the entrance of young ROBERT THE BRUCE, a handsome young man, full of intelligence and power.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Robert strides to his seat in the center of the table, and the others settle in respectfully. MORNAY, another young warrior, gives him a bow, as does CRAIG, a grizzled noble.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Among these was Robert, the 17th Earl of Bruce, a leading contender for the crown of Scotland.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Young Robert, we are honored -- ROBERT My father hears that Longshanks has granted prima noctes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Clearly meant to draw more of his supporters here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Balliol clan has endorsed the right, licking Longshanks' boots so he will support their claim to the throne. If we make a show of opposition, the commoners will favor us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is too soon to step out alone. My father believes we must lull Longshanks into confidence, by neither supporting his decree nor opposing it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A wise plan. And how is your father? We have missed him at the council.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He strained his leg so that it pains him to ride. But he sends his greetings -- and says that I speak for all the Bruces. And for Scotland.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: EXT.
location: SCOTTISH VILLAGE, AT THE EDGE OF TOWN

direction.raw_text: Flutes and dancing; laughter and garlands; village families have gathered for a wedding celebration -- we see the happy bride and groom. Farmers cart in fresh bread and hoops of cheese; villagers arrive with casks of beer or strings of smoked fish. And watching the people are ubiquitous English soldiers, battlescarred veterans with missing eyes and ears. Riding along the road comes William Wallace. Grown now, a man. He sits his horse as if born there, his back straight, his hands relaxed on the reins. He has a look of lean, rippled power. He looks dangerous. And the soldiers notice him, nudging each other as he passes. He carries a dead wild goose hanging across his saddle; he stops his horse at the edge of the clearing and surveys the scene. Farmers are roasting a pig; women are comparing handiwork; young men are tossing huge stones in the traditional Highland games -- and everyone is noticing William's arrival, especially the farm women with daughters of marriageable age. Among those watching William arrive is Campbell, grown older now; and with his old rebel friend, MacClannough. William dismounts and ties his horse to a willow. One of the English SOLDIERS shoves William from behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William's eyes fix themselves on the soldier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His buddies, enjoying their role as intimidators, grab the bird and begin to search it for evidence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They don't believe that -- but they can't find any puncture wound on the bird. William reaches his hand out for the return of the bird. The soldiers drop it onto the ground. Slowly, William picks it up, and heads into the clearing. The farmers watch him come. Among those noticing William's arrival, but pretending not to, is MARION MacCLANNOUGH, grown now into a stunning young woman; her long auburn hair reminds us of those years long ago; she wears it the same way, straight and full down her back. Her dress is plain, like the grass that surrounds a wildflower. She's the most beautiful girl in the village, maybe in all of Scotland, and the soldiers who hassled William notice her too. William reaches the food table and contributes his goose to the feast. FARM WOMEN eye him; he nodes to one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The daughter mentioned is missing teeth. William nods to her. It's impossible for him to giver her a smile as bright as her hopes, and she lowers her head in disappointment. But then raises her face in surprise as William takes her hand and gives her a respectful bow. He moves away from the table, passing through the crowd like a stranger. Then he glances toward the knot of girls. He sees Marion. She sees him, then looks away. Do they remember each other? He moves toward her; she is shy, her eyes downcast, but then she raises them and looks at him. They move closer and closer together. Just as they are about to reach each other, a huge round stone THUMPS to the earth at Williams' feet. He looks up to see one of Marion's suitors -- the broad, muscled young man who has just tossed the stone in William's way. Now everybody's looking to see how William will handle the challenge. He tries to move around, but the guy cuts him off. Then William thinks he recognizes the big red-head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is his old friend, but Hamish won't admit it, or be put off from the challenge. He points to the huge stone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He taps his temple. Hamish stretches out his hand, as if to show William something in his palm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a sudden movement, he slams his fist into William's jaw, dropping him. A few men move to interfere, but Campbell, MacClannough, and the other farmers who are the true leaders here, stop their neighbors from interrupting. Hamish stands over William, waiting for him to get up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William stands and hoists the huge stone, eighteen inches in diameter. Straining with the effort, he lugs the stone to the line scratched in the rocky field. Beyond the line are the muddy dents from previous tosses. William takes a run and heaves the stone. It flies past the other marks in the field; people are impressed. William looks at Hamish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hamish walks out, lifts the stone, and lugs it back to the line. He takes a run and heaves with a great groan! The stone flies, passing William's mark by a couple of feet. People laugh and whistle. William nods, impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William walks to the dent made by Hamish's throw.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hamish scowls at William, at everybody watching. He lifts the stone and carries it back to the line. William stands calmly. Hamish backs up for his run. William yawns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hamish backs up a few more feet, for a longer run.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William seems completely unafraid. He leans down, picks up a small smooth stone and tosses it up in the air casually. Stung by this show of calm, Hamish takes furious run, and heaves! The stone flies through the air, just misses William's head, and buries itself halfway into the earth behind him. William never flinches. The people cheer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hamish is miffed; it's like William won.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William turns, walks double the distance Hamish threw, and turns and hurls the rock he holds! It whistles through the air, hits Hamish in the forehead, and drops him like a shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody cheers and laughs! They surround William.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William takes a tankard of ale from a farmer, walks over and tosses the cold liquid into Hamish's face; he wakes, and, his eyes uncrossing, accepts William's hand, pulling him up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grinning, they embrace. MUSIC plays, the dancing begins. William walks to the knot of young ladies... but passes Marion, and moves to the girl with the missing teeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's thrilled to accept; they begin to dance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The musicians interrupt their playing; a group of heavily armed horsemen, with banners and flying colors, ride up, reining their horses into the middle of the celebration. In the middle of the group is an English NOBLEMAN; he is gray, in his fifties, and stops in front of the BRIDE and groom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stewart, father of the BRIDE, lunges forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The horsemen point their lances at the unarmed Scots -- who see that the English soldiers from the village have moved to the edge of the gathering, as if to dare any resistance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Even unarmed, Stewart is about to attack -- but the bride intervenes. She grabs her father and whispers to him. She moves to her husband and does the same. Holding back tears, she allows herself to be pulled up behind one of the horsemen. Marion MacClannough is looking on, sobered by her friend's courage and sickened by her fate -- and Marion is even more unsettled as she notices that one of the soldiers, a particularly nasty looking brute with a scarred face, is leering at her. William Wallace sees this too. The noble and his escorts ride away, and as they do it begins to rain. The celebration destroyed, the Scots gather the food and disperse to their homes. But Wallace remains, standing in the downpour, keeping his thoughts to himself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey boy! You hunt this bird?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's against the law for Scots to own bows. You shot this bird?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hit it in the head. With a rock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Miz MacDougal. You look well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...William? It's William Wallace, back home! -- Have you met my daughter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hamish?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Test of manhood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You win.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (blocks him) Call it a test of soldiery, then. The English won't let us train with weapons, so we train with stones.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The test of a soldier is not in his arm. It's here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. It's here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A contest, then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I still say this is no test. A catapult can throw a stone farther than a man can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That depends on the man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you do it when it matters? As it matters in battle? Could you crush a man with that throw?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I could crush you like a roach.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then do it. Come, do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll move
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not fair!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's tired, he should get a longer run.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Brave show!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I threw longer than last time!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An ox is strong, but not clever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An ox is stupid enough to just stand in one place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not the point.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A fine display, young Wallace!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good to see you again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I should'a remembered the eggs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you honor me with a dance?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've taken over your father's farm? (beat) They say he died long ago. Fighting the English.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He died in an accident, with my brother. Their cart turned over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have come to claim the right of prima noctes. As the lord of these lands, I will bless this marriage by taking the bride into my bed on the first night of her union.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, by God!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is my noble right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The farmhouse looks lonely and forlorn. William stands at the open door, and gazes out at the rain; it leaks on him, through his roof; he doesn't seem to notice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A thatched cottage, lit with a cozy fire, beneath the rain. A hand KNOCKS on the door, and MacClannough opens it to find William, on a horse! MacClannough frowns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. MacClannough shoulders up beside her husband, and Marion appears behind her scowling parents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marion has grabbed a cloak off the back of the door; she runs out to hop up behind William, and they gallop away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good evening, sir. May I speak with your daughter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Marion... Would you like to go for a ride on this fine evening?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The boy's insane!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's good Scottish weather, Madam, the rain is fallin' straight down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She absolutely may not, she'll -- Marion!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: William and Marion race along the heather, up and down hills, through swollen streams. The rain stops, as the sun sets; the Scottish mists lift, revealing stunning natural beauty. William stops the horse and they look out over it all together. He speaks, without turning to face her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lingers; he wants to say something, or maybe he just doesn't want the moment to end. Finally he spurs the horse.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Your father doesn't like me, does he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not you. He dislikes that you're a Wallace. He just says... the Wallaces don't seem to live for very long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you for accepting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you for inviting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll invite you again, but your mother thinks I'm crazy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are. And I'll come again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They reach the door. William hops off the horse and reaches up to help her down the moment she touches the ground, they look into each other's eyes... but the door is snatched open so quickly by her mother that there is not time for a kiss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks her closer to the door. They turn and look at each other again. She waits for him to kiss her...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She still hesitates; he isn't going to kiss her. She starts in, but he grabs her hand. And into it he puts something he has taken from his pocket; it is wrapped in flannel. He hops on his horse, glances at her, and gallops away. She stands in the open doorway; she looks down at what he left her. She unwraps the flannel; it is a dried thistle, the one she gave him years before.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Marion, come in!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Marion, come in!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: William is re-thatching the roof of his barn, when he hears riders approaching, and looks down to see that it is MacClannough, backed by Campbell and Hamish. Uh-oh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William goes back to repairing his roof.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Campbell shakes his head and reins his horse away, with Hamish. MacClannough lingers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MacClannough rides away. William sits down on the roof, and looks out at the graves of his father and brother.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Young Wallace -- WILLIAM Sir, I know it was strange of me to invite Marion to ride last night. I assure you, I -- CAMPBELL MacClannough's daughter is another matter. We come to fetch you to a meeting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What kind of meeting?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The secret kind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your father was a fighter. And a patriot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know who my father was. I came back home to raise crops. And, God willing, a family. If I can live in peace, I will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you can keep your intention to stay out of the troubles, you may court my daughter. If you break your intention, I'll kill you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Outside the half-timbered house, William stands in the shadows of moonlight and tosses a pebble against the wooden upper window. Marion opens the shutters and slips out onto the vines, dropping into William's arms. Giggling, suppressing laughter, they run to the trees...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hand in hand through the heather they run, silhouettes along a ridge, their breath blowing silver clouds in the moonlight, the Scottish wind whipping through their hair. They stop at a grove at the edge of a precipice, overlooking a loch gleaming in the moonlight. So beautiful it's sacred.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at her. They kiss suddenly, so long and hard that they tumble into the heather, rolling, devouring each other. Through their passion...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They kiss again...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You've been here before?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some nights. I have dreams. Mostly dreams I don't want. I started riding at night to fill up my mind so that when I did sleep I'd dream only of the ride and the adventure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did it work?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. You don't choose your dreams. Your dreams choose you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want... to marry you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... accept your proposal!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not just saying it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nor I!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I won't give you up to any nobleman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stopping) You scare me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to scare you. I want to be yours, and you mine. Every night like this one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This night is too beautiful to have again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will be with you, like this. Forever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Marion moves through the market. English soldiers admire her as she walks. She stops, looking at white lace and cloth. William casually passes, poking a note in her basket. Subtly she withdraws his note, and reads:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tonight. By the trees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marion slips out of the house and runs to the trees, where William waits with horses. She fetches a bundle she's stashed in the crook of a tree, and they mount and ride off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The church is at the base of the precipice, beside the loch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This ancient Gaelic place of worship has been destroyed by the occupying army, and yet it looks devoutly holy this way, lit only by candles and moonlight through the open roof. The village PRIEST whom we saw at the wedding celebration is waiting at the altar. Marion steps into the confessional, as William moves to the altar and kneels in prayer. Marion emerges; she's changed into the wedding dress she made from the cloth she bought. William stands and watches her float down the aisle; his whole life was worth this moment. Together, the two lovers turn to the priest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From within his shirt, William withdraws a strip of cloth woven in his family tartan. He and Marion each lift a hand to the priest, and he binds their wrists with the cloth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From her dress she takes a handmade handkerchief, embroidered with a thistle to look like the one she first gave him those years ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Priest waits for them to go on, but neither can; they're too taken with emotion, looking at each other. The Priest intones holy phrases...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The lovers kiss. As they break their embrace, a figure carrying something dark and spiky appears at the broken door of the church, and William spins as if to attack, but the Priest catches his arm; they see the man carries bagpipes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The piper begins to play, and the tune from his primitive chanter is wispy, ethereal, beautiful. The lovers look into each other's eyes, as the single melody of the pipes merges into a swell of music, UNDERSCORING MONTAGE William and Marion ride the path to the top of the precipice, where, in the shelter of the grove, they spend their honeymoon. The MUSIC CONTINUES as, still sweaty from their love-making, he returns her to her house just before dawn. She waves from her window, as William rides away, as we
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You have come to pledge, each to the other, before Almighty God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will love you my whole life. You and no other.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I you. You and no other. Forever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Agus bhayd lauch... The Lord bless and keep thy love, now and forever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I trust him -- or I'd'a killed him me'self. A weddin' needs pipes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It's Market Day in the village, busy with Highlanders, merchants of all kinds, and a few special attractions like jugglers and fortune tellers. Marion moves along a table full of flowers and fruit... William, concealed behind hanging baskets, watches her unseen, savoring the beauty of his beloved, bathing his soul in the sight of her. Then she looks up and spots him, her smile sudden and luminous, before she remembers to conceal it. He moves up beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Playfully he pokes his finger under the collar of her dress, pulling up the strip of checked cloth he gave her at their wedding, which she now wears hidden around her neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tucking in the cloth strip, she hurries away, smiling.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I've missed you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shush. It's only been a day. (beat) And it's seemed like forever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tonight then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My parents are growing suspicious! I can't keep meeting you every night!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then when?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Tonight!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - BY AN ALE CASK - DAY They spot Marion moving through the fair, glowing, beautiful. The soldiers smirk at each other; as Marion passes, one of them grabs her wrist. It's the soldier with the scar, the one who's been staring at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A second drunken SOLDIER pipes up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The scarred soldier pulls Marion into his big arms; she shoves him away with surprising strength, and he staggers back, to the laughter of his friends. Then he snatches her again and kisses her hard on the lips. She breaks free and SLAPS him fiercely, hard enough to draw blood from his mouth. Tasting the trickle, he slings her down against sacks of grain, and the soldiers are all over her, pinning her down, ripping her clothes, a full scale public gang rape. As the townspeople try to move in the three soldiers waiting their turn at Marion pull their knives, keep them townspeople back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He slams his mouth down against hers for a long, awful time, comes up clawing at her dress to rip it from her body... and is hit in the face by a rock thrown at great speed! It takes a moment for the other soldiers to realize what just happened, and in that instant William is on them. He wrenches one soldier's arm in a direction it was never meant to go, breaking the elbow, separating the shoulder, and slinging the howling soldier into his comrades. Two of the soldiers leap at William, swinging their short swords; William ducks, knocking their ale cask into their knees; William lifts the whole table where they were sitting and slams it into the faces of two more attackers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shouts to warn him that the scarred soldier, now bloodyfaced, has recovered from the rock and is behind William with a knife. William sidesteps the first thrust, snatches a leg from the shattered table and crushes the man's skull.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But there's no time for celebration. There's blood and ale everywhere, and the fallen soldiers are yelling...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where are you going... lass?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 Why don't you marry my friend here? Then I'll take the first night!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Bitch, who do you think you are?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: William!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wallace Wallace! William Wallace!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rebels! Help!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: hear the call and come running, reinforcements converging from all over the village.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will sees the horse that pulled the flower cart and throws Marion up onto its back. He slaps the horse's rump and it plunges with Marion into the twisting village lanes. William darts off through the crowd, as the MAGISTRATE and more of his soldiers arrive -- dozens of them! William pauses out in the central street of the village, just long enough to be sure they've spotted him, and darts into a side lane in the opposite direction Marion went; William weaves through the narrow streets of the medieval town, knocking over baskets, jumping carts. As the soldiers stumble after him, the Magistrate looks down at his mangled soldiers. The one with the ruptured arm is lying in agony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The shout rings through the village; Marion hears it, and when she sees more soldiers at the far end of the lane she's trying to take out of town, she urges the horse into an even narrower back alley. She sees a clear route to freedom... But the flock of pigeons pecking on the scraps thrown there behind the shops rise into the horse's face with a sudden thrashing of wings, and the horse shies against a wall. Marion controls him, but a flap of her ripped dress has caught on a crude nail, and as the frightened horse lunges forward again, she is pulled off its bare back, her dress catching and ripping at the same time, dropping her hard.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Run, William! Run!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What girl?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...on horse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The girl on the horse! Stop her!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: reaches the edge of the town and slips into the trees by the river; the soldiers are running every which way, but they've lost him. Thinking Marion's made it too, William heads deeper into the trees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: recovers; her dress has torn free! She starts to get up; but the soldiers' pikes appear over her, and the magistrate leers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So this is the little whore he was fighting for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: William moves into the shelters of the trees, expecting to see Marion. He doesn't. He listens; only the rustling of the wind through the treetops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing, except the wind.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Marion!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Marion is thrown into a chair and her arms are bound with an oak staff behind her elbows. She and two dozen soldiers are in the tavern the English have commandeered. The Magistrate is a battlescarred veteran, a brutal pragmatist angry with his CORPORAL.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He studies Marion, her mouth now stuffed with burlap. He notices the strip of cloth around her neck, and touches the weave curiously.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: One Scot buggers six of us? Hell to pay when that gets round.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Burn the village.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But he is free. You never catch 'em in the Highlands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Clans weave that cloth in their own patterns.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So why is this strip concealed? (beat) He fought for you, eh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Magistrate and his men bring Marion into the village center, and tie her to a post of the well. The townspeople don't want to be near the soldiers, but they hang on the fringes of the square, too curious to pull away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks down at Marion, her mouth bound, her eyes defiant. He jerks out his dagger and slices Marion's throat! Her eyes spring open like a doe's; then she sags, dead. The townspeople are speechless; even some of the soldiers are shocked. The Magistrate turns calmly to his men.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: An assault on the king's soldiers is the same as assaulting the king!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now. Let this scrapper come to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE GROVE AT THE PRECIPICE - DAY From a distance, we see Hamish approaching the grove, the same one where he and William played as boys. Hamish moves reluctantly, forcing himself forward; as he reaches the grove, William appears, hurrying out to him. We STAY IN THE LONG SHOT, seeing William asking anxiously for any news, and seeing Hamish's great shoulders as he tells him something that makes William step backwards...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At a barrier across the main road into the center of the village are twenty professional soldiers, entrenched, fully armed -- bows, pikes, swords. They hear A HORSE'S SNORT...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has stopped, rock still. The soldiers hush; there is something unsettling about this man alone, staring at the twenty of them, as if to steel himself for the butchery. Wallace raises his sword, screams... and charges!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VARIOUS ANGLES - LANARK VILLAGE - DAY - THE FIGHT We FAVOR WALLACE'S SUBJECTIVE POV: the barrier as his horse pounds toward it, the faces of the enemy soldiers with their eyes white with fear... They stand to shoot at him with their bows; the arrows WHISH toward the lens, fly past... The arrows tear through Wallace's clothes, but don't catch his flesh. He charges on; his horse LEAPS the barrier as Wallace simultaneously swings the broadsword -- and he's more than an expert: the tip, at the end of a huge arc, nearly breaks the sound barrier and the blade bites through the corporal's helmet, taking off the upper half of his head! The soldiers try to rally, to shoot him in the back as his horse leaps over them. One of them has sighted William's back... But Hamish and his father crash into them! It's a wild fight; old Campbell takes an arrow through the shoulder but keeps hacking with his sword; Hamish batters down two men -- and more Scots arrive! They overwhelm the soldiers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - FAVORING HIS POV He dodges obstacles in the narrow streets -- chickens, carts, barrels. Soldiers pop up; the first he gallops straight over; the next he whacks forehand, like a polo player; the next chops down on his left side; every time he swings the broadsword, a man dies. Wallace gallops on; his farmer neighbors, and people from the village, follow in his wake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Magistrate hears the APPROACHING SHOUTS. He and thirty more of his men are barricaded around the village square.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The see Wallace gallop into sight; but he stops, then heads down a side street. The Magistrate and his men don't like this; where did he go? Which way will he come from? And then they hear the horses, and see the other Scots, at the head of the main street. The soldiers unleash a volley of arrows at them. They are loading to fire again when Wallace runs in -- on foot! -- and cuts down two soldiers! The other Scots charge! The startled soldiers break and run in every direction. The Magistrate, abandoned, runs too. Wallace pursues. Not far along a twisting lane, the bulky Magistrate falters. He turns to fight, and Wallace slashes away his sword.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't look surprised! We knew he'd bring friends!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! I beg you... mercy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As the Scots see Wallace, they break off pursuing the English soldiers and stop to watch; dragging the Magistrate by his hair, Wallace hauls him back into the village square, slams him against the well, and stands over him with heaving lungs and wild eyes, staring at Marion's murderer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace's eyes shift, falling on
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Please. Mercy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Marion's blood, in a dark dry splash by the wall of the well, the stain dripping down onto the dirt of the street. Wallace spins, jerks back the Magistrate's head, and cuts his throat with the sword.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silenced by what they've just seen and done. On old Campbell's face is a look of reverence, and awe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William staggers a few steps, and collapses to his knees. And then not just the Scottish farmers but the townspeople too begin a strange, Hi-Lo chant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William's wild eyes slowly regain their focus. And there in the dirt beside the well, he sees the severed cloth strip he gave to Marion, now stained with her blood. He lifts it, crushes it in his hand, as the Highlanders chant for war.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Say Grace to God, lads. We've just seen the coming of the Messiah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ! AHHHHHH-UHHHHHH!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The villagers are still excited by what just happened; at the blacksmith's forge, men tend to Campbell's wound...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They obey, then take a glowing poker from the fire and run it through Campbell's shoulder, where the arrow went. There is a terrible SIZZLE, and Campbell reacts to the pain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Campbell looks down at his left hand. His thumb is missing!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace is sitting alone nearby, staring at nothing. Hamish moves over and puts a hand on his shoulder. Wallace looks at his friend, and looks away; killing the Magistrate did not bring Marion back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Pour it straight into the wound. I know it seems a waste of good whiskey, but indulge me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah. Now that'll clear your sinuses, lads.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well bloody Hell, look at this! Now it's nothing but a fly swatter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: of alarm: ARMED MEN are coming! The farmers scramble for their weapons, ready to fight; even Campbell jumps up; but what they see coming out of the darkness are twenty more farmers, with hayhooks, knives, axes, anything they could find for weapons. Their leader is MacGREGOR.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MacGregor leads his men into the circle of rebels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all look at Wallace.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: MacGregor -- from the next valley!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We heard about what was happenin'. And we don't want ya thinkin' ya can have your fun without us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go home. Some of us are in this, I can't help that now. But you can help yourselves. Go home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll have no homes left when the English garrison at the castle comes through to burn us out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Furious preparations: armorers pound breastplates, hone spears, grind swords in a shower of sparks. The garrison is led by BOTTOMS, the English lord who claimed the right of prima noctes. Now he shouts to his scurrying soldiers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell him that I will hang five rebels for every good Englishman killed! FORM FOR MARCH! The troops begin to scramble into the courtyard. At the same time, the messenger gallops to the gate and nods for the keepers to open it. They pull up the chains and the heavy gate rises. The messenger spurs his horse to gallop through -- and is hit in the chest with an axe! The Scots, hidden just outside the gate, come pouring through, led by Wallace! Arrows pick soldiers from their perches, Scots drop over the wall; the surprise is so complete that it's over almost without a fight. Lord Bottoms looks around in confusion...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scots drag Lord Bottoms off his horse; an arrow in a flexed bow jabs right up to his eye, the archer ready to drive the shaft through Bottom's eye socket and into his brain; but Wallace's hand closes on the archer's fingers -- and Bottoms sees that the archer at the other end of the arrow shaft is none other than the Highland farmgirl he forced into his bed on her wedding night. Beside her is her husband, holding a scythe, red with English blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The point of Wallace's sword jumps beneath the Lord's chin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The green eyes of the defiled highland bride flash fire. William takes his hand from her bow and looks at her, grief for Marion in his eyes; for the sake of that she does not release the string.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hamish extends the reins of the Lord's thoroughbred.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods to a bony nag hitched next to a glue pot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the Scots cheer, Wallace throws Lord Bottoms onto the nag's back and slaps the horse's rear. IT shambles away, followed by the English survivors, as the Scots chant...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Gather the horses! Align the infantry! (grabs a man) Ride to the Lord Governor in Stirling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop them... Don't let... Align...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On your way somewhere, M'lord?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Murdering bloody bandit!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My name is William Wallace. I am no bandit who hides his face... Find this man a horse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give him a horse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not this horse. That one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Today we will spare you, and every man who has yielded. Go back to England. Tell them Scotland's daughters and her sons are yours no more. Tell them Scotland is free.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wal-lace, Wal-lace, Wal-lace!...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXT. HIGHLANDS - DAY The marker is carved with the name MARION MacCLANNOUGH, and beneath her name A THISTLE is chiseled into the stone. Bagpipes wail like banshees and the Priest who married Marion and William now mutters ancient prayers as her body, wrapped in burial canvas, is lowered into the earth, under the sad eyes of those who just fought in the battle. Opposite William stands old MacClannough; he stares across the open hole that accepts the body of his daughter, his eyes full of pain, and then staggers away. Wallace kneels at the graveside in unspeakable grief. From within his shirt he withdraws the embroidered handkerchief she gave him, and the bloodstained strip of cloth he gave her. He places the strip over her heart, and as the gravediggers fill the hole her returns the handkerchief to its spot over his own heart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prince Edward is in his garden, playing the medieval version of croquet with his friend. The Princess, ignored, sits watching. Longshanks marches through the game, furious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Longshanks slaps his son, knocking him down among the colored balls and wickets. Everyone gasps, stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Longshanks jerks him to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Longshanks grabs his son by the throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The king leaves. The friends of the humiliated Prince hurry to him and lift him; as the Princess moves to him too...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He slaps her! Her personal guards, Frenchmen in distinctive uniforms, jump from their seats at the edge of the garden, but the Princess raises a hand to show she needs no assistance, and curtseys to Edward, who shouts -- EDWARD Convene my military council! As Edward marches off with his entourage, NICOLETTE, a beautiful raven-haired Handmaiden, rushes to the Princess, who is wobbly, hurt more than she let show. Nicolette whispers to her in French, with subtitles...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Scottish rebels have routed Lord Bottoms!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hear. This Wallace is a bandit, nothing more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You weak little coward! Stand up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I go to France to press our rights there! I leave you to handle this little rebellion, do you understand? DO YOU?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And turn yourself into a man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get away from me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They say this Wallace killed thirty men to avenge the death of his woman. I hope your husband goes to Scotland. Then you'll be a widow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Robert the Bruce is in bed with a young Nordic beauty with vacant blue eyes. She drowses; but the lovemaking has not defused the restlessness of Robert's spirit. He lies on his stomach, turned away from her on the bed. Stirring, she kisses his neck; but he doesn't respond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he is numb as she nuzzles him again. She sags back, and he still stares away, lost in thought. Realizing her hurt, he explains...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him blankly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I wanted to please you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In Lanark village, the king's soldiers killed a girl. Her lover fought his way through the soldiers and killed the magistrate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He rebelled. He rebelled. He acted. He fought! Was it rage? Pride? Love? Whatever it was, he has more of it than I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hurt) You might have lied.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm too arrogant to lie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: On his FACE as he moves grimly up a dark castle staircase. He follows a servant who carries a candle against the gloom. They reach a door, which the servant unlocks. Young Robert takes the candle, and enters -- A DARKENED ROOM Robert wills himself forward, and places the candle on a table in the center of the room. A SHUFFLE in the dark; then moving into the light is a LEPER whose once-noble features are decaying with the disease. Isolated in his disfiguration, he looks at his visitor -- his son -- with the eyes of the condemned. Young Robert forces himself not to look away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The old man thinks, and points a half finger at his son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Young Bruce rises heavily, and moves to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a last long look at his father, Robert leaves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Father. A rebellion has begun.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Under whom?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A commoner named William Wallace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A commoner? So no one leads Scotland?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You will embrace this rebellion. Support it, from our lands in the north. I will gain English favor by condemning it and ordering it opposed from our lands in the south. Whichever way the tide runs, we will rise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This Wallace. He doesn't even have a knighthood. But he fights with passion, and he is clever. He inspires men.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You admire him. Uncompromising men are easy to admire. He has courage. So does a dog. But you must understand this: Edward Longshanks is the most ruthless king ever to sit on the throne of England, and none of us, and nothing of Scotland, will survive unless we are as ruthless, more ruthless, than he.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Press your case to the nobles. They will choose who rules Scotland.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Troops ride through the countryside, intimidating and questioning civilians; all refuse to talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace's house burns, as soldiers dig up the graves of his father and brother, and scatter their bones to dogs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The English search through the woods, finding nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William and Hamish ride, to see the damage. They find the smoking ruins, and the defiled family graves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William is struck by an awful, urgent thought...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, William... I am so sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We open on Marion's grave, with the thistle-carved marker, looking peaceful; but up the hill in the underbrush, English soldiers wait in ambush. Edgy, they perk up at the sound of muffled hoofbeats -- then their eyes bug as a cloaked figure -- Wallace -- suddenly looms up behind them, galloping and swirling fire! He hurls burning torches into the clustered soldiers, setting some of them on fire!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: has crawled to Marion's grave and is digging frantically. The new dirt parts easily and he pulls the shrouded body out, cringing with the effort.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: rush from behind the rocks at the far side of the graveyard. Wallace charges them, driving them back. He grabs the reins of Hamish's horse, hidden among trees, and gallops to him. Hamish hands the shrouded body up to William and bounds into the saddle of his own horse. They spur the horses and ride away, William clutching Marion's shrouded body to his chest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William dismounts, stretching the body gently on the ground. Hamish dismounts too, with the spade he used to dig up the old grave. He sees the emotion on William's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hamish puts a hand on his friend's shoulder, then quietly leads the horses away. William starts to dig...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'll wait... back there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hamish, I... thank...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: William sits looking at the new grave, covered with leaves -- completely hidden. He touches his hand to the earth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hamish is waiting as William comes out of the grove. There is nothing to say. They mount their horses and ride away, as the MUSIC of William and Marion's love haunts us...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace and his inner circle hare huddled around a small fire. Other highlanders guard the perimeters.
