Old Campbell is lovingly honing the broadswords to razor edges and sharing a whiskey jug with Hamish, who stares at the fire. Wallace is using a stick to draw diagrams in the dirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At a loss, Wallace looks up at the sky. HE SEES: the trees stretching into the night like spikes to skewer the stars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look to see a half dozen new volunteers being led in, blindfolded. When the guides remove the blindfolds, the new recruits see Wallace and rush to him, bowing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he reaches into his cloak, both Hamish and Campbell instantly draw their swords and put the points to his neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carefully, Faudron pulls out a beautiful tartan scarf, and replaces Wallace's tattered old one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A loud voice interrupts...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all look at a slender, handsome young man, STEPHEN, who is talking to himself -- or more accurately, seems to listen to some unheard voice, then answer it...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stephen whips a dagger from his sleeve and puts it at Campbell's throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace jerks his sword to the Irishman's throat, and grins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stephen grins, and happily tucks away the dagger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace shakes his head and moves back to the fire, as the sentries take the newcomers to find their own spaces.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What're ya doin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thinking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does it hurt?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do we do when Longshanks sends his whole northern army against us? They have heavy cavalry. Armored horses, that shake the very ground. They'll ride right over us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We make spears. A hundred spears. Fourteen feet long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fourteen? -- SENTRY (O.S.) Volunteers coming in!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: William Wallace? We have come to fight and die for you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stand up, man, I'm not the Pope.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am Faudron! My sword is yours! And I brought you this tarta --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We checked them for arms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's your family tartan! My wife wove it with her own hands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank her for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Him? That can't be William Wallace! I'm prettier than this man!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, Father, I'll ask him! (to William) If I risk my neck for you, will I get a chance to kill Englishmen?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is your Poppa a ghost -- or do you converse with God Almighty?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In order to find his equal, and Irishman is forced to talk to God. (quickly) Yes, Father!... (to Wallace) The Almighty says don't change the subject, just answer the fookin' question.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Insane Irish --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Smart enough to get a dagger past your guards, old man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's my friend, Irishman. And the answer's yes. You fight for me, you kill the English.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excellent! Stephen is my name. I'm the most wanted man on the Emerald Isle. Except I'm not on the Emerald Isle of course, more's the pity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A common thief.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A patriot!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A column of English light cavalry -- a hundred riders -- moves through the picturesque beauty of the Highlands. English LORD DOLECROFT is in command, wearing a hat with a pompous white plume. UP AHEAD, the English SCOUT sees five Scots, including Hamish, walking out of the forest. The Scots run; the Scout rides back to Dolecroft.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The English force charges off. Hamish and his men changed direction but the English spot them crossing a hilltop and ride after them. The Scots run for their lives; the English horses gallop. The Scots run down one slope, up another; the English follow, find their horses stumbling, and see...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But as they move toward the firm ground, fifty Scots appear on the crest of the hill. Hamish leads them, smiling. Dolecroft wheels and looks to his rear; Wallace appears there, with fifty more, and more Scots appear to the left and right of the English, who are surrounded in the bog. Too late, Dolecroft realizes his blunder. Wallace lifts his broadsword, screams, and leads the charge...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Scotsmen, Sire! Headed west!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They've blundered at last! After them!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're in a bog!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here, it's firm this way --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Scots are moving through deep woods; they are laden with the booty they took from the English cavalry: extra weapons, clothing, food -- and one man even wears the late Dolecroft's plumed hat. Wallace is leading them, traveling with his heavy sheathed broadsword across his shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They collapse to the leaves and loam, greedily squeezing water from sheep belly canteens.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stop here and rest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: English commander, is handed news of the disaster. He reads the message, and pales.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Another ambush! My God! ...What about our infiltrator?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He has already joined them, M'lord.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The moon is high above the Scots, encamped for the night. Most everyone is sleeping, but William sits leaning against a tree, lost in lonely thoughts. Suddenly William freezes; a shaft of moonlight illuminates a cloaked woman standing twenty feet ahead of him. Something about her is familiar -- and then she pulls off the hood, revealing her auburn hair, cascading in the moonlight... It is Marion!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joy explodes on his face, and he runs to her, but stops before he touches her, as if she might evaporate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William clutches at Marion, but his arms can't enclose her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Marion! Is... is it you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm dreaming.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, you are. And you must wake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to wake. I want to stay with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I with you. But you must wake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I need you so much! I love you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wake up, William. Wake up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wake up, William!...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wake up!...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: lying on his new tartan, in camp, with Hamish shaking him, William's arms clutched empty to his chest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace jumps up, hearing the DISTANT BARKING that alarmed Hamish. Stephen, the new Irish recruit, races up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shoving groups of men in different directions, Wallace then takes off. His group is about a dozen; they race through the woods, dodging trees, running aimlessly. They stop and listen. The BARKS are getting closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again they divide, and race in different directions. But no matter how they run and dodge, the BARKS grow nearer. We INTERCUT with the approaching of the dogs -- a large PACK OF HOUNDS, with keepers like on a fox hunt, and behind the dogs, Lord Pickering, with his soldiers, prepared for a long chase, cloaked against the wet darkness, carrying torches. Wallace and others pause, hear the dogs, and run again, in a new direction. The hounds are relentless. Wallace's group is down to Hamish, Stephen, and Faudron.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Faster now, faster. The barks are getting very close. Wallace and his friends are starting to panic. The blood beats in their ears, their breath scalds their lungs. And we MOVE IN on Wallace's eyes. He stops, gasping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace pulls out his dagger...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: William! Hounds!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We must run in different directions!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We don't split up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They used hounds on us in Ireland, it's the only way!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's right, Hamish! Campbell! Divide them and run!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Split again!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No matter how we go, they follow. They have our scent. My scent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Run! You must not be caught!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We can't stop!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They've tricked us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the crazy man saying, Lord?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The dogs have a scent. My scent. Someone must have given it to them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

The handlers must fight furiously to tear the dogs from the body. Lord Pickering approaches the body and looks down. It is Faudron, mangled now but clearly identifiable -- with the scarf he gave William, in place of William's own, tucked into his shirt.

direction.raw_text: Pickering's eyes go wide, then roll back as Stephen's dagger slides expertly through his back ribs and into his heart. As Pickering falls and his men realize what has happened, Stephen has already run back into the trees. Pickering's men freeze at this sudden turn of events. Even the dogs whimper, picking up the rising fear of the men around them. Then from the darkness all around them comes a chorus of demonic, bloodcurdling yells -- WALLACE/HAMISH/STEPHEN ARRRRRGGGGGGGHHHH! Three wild men tear out of the darkness from different directions, their swords slashing. Pickering's men panic and run, their dogs yelping, and the other soldiers, evident by their torches, fell with them in all directions. Wallace, Hamish and Stephen are left alone in the heart of the woods, howling, barking like dogs, snarling like wolves -- and then laughing like hyenas!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They laugh again; then Wallace's laughter leaks away, and he stares into the trees, where he saw Marion in his dream.

direction.raw_text: The English knights see the signal banners, telling them to attack. They take the lances from their squires, and lower the visors of their helmets. Proud, plumed, glimmering; they look invincible. Their huge horses, themselves draped in scarlet and purple, look like tanks. The knights charge! Their hooves THUNDER; the horses are so heavy the ground literally shakes with the charge. The Scots stand and watch them come on. It's difficult to imagine the courage this takes; from the POV OF THE SCOTTISH LINES we see the massive horses boring in... we feel the RISING THUNDER of the charge, closer, closer... Wallace moves to the front of the lead group of Scots.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now the spearmen snap the spears forward in ranks, the first line of men bracing their spears at an angle three feet above the ground, the men behind them bracing theirs at a five foot level, the men behind that bracing at seven feet. The English knights have never seen such a formation. Their lances are useless and it's too late to stop! The momentum that was to carry the horses smashing through the men on foot now becomes suicidal force; knights and horses impale themselves on the long spears like beef on skewers.

At the rear of the hall is a balcony, backed by a magnificent sunlit stained glass window, and in the center of its rainbow corona he sees a familiar form: Marion, so real to him in this moment of triumph that he can see her, glowing like an angel, in a gown worthy of the occasion. direction.raw_text: Wallace and his men are marching away, as Robert the Bruce runs out after them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace walks; Robert catches up and speaks to him in an urgent half whisper, so that no one else can hear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace walks away, leaving Robert the Bruce alone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wait! ...I respect what you said. But remember, these men have lands, castles. Much to risk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And the common man who bleeds on the battlefield, does he risk less?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. But from top to bottom this country has no sense of itself. Its nobles share allegiance with England and its clans war with each other. If you make enemies on both sides of the border, you'll end up dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We all end up dead. It's only a question of how. And why.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm no coward! I want what you want! But we need the nobles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobles? What does that mean -- to be noble? Your title gives you claim to the throne of our country. But men don't follow titles, they follow courage! Your arm speaks louder than your tongue. Our people know you. Noble and common, they respect you. If you would lead them toward freedom, they would follow you. And so would I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Wallace rides at the head of his army, moving through the countryside of northern England. It is autumn, the foliage is beautiful, the wheat fields gold with harvest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ESTABLISHING YORK CITY - DAY A medieval city guarded by a fortress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The ROYAL GOVERNOR is a spoiled young man, Longshanks' nephew. He is studying maps and written appeals for help; his CAPTAIN of defenses strides in with another note.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They hear shouts as a rider arrives and dismounts. They look out to see a panicked RIDER, who shouts up...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Message from your cousin, the Prince. He says London has no more troops to send.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Every town in Northern England is begging for help! Where will Wallace strike first?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I should think these smaller settlements along the border...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He advances!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To what town?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He comes here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: IC DOWN A ROAD as civilians flee the walled city in the distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: has cut a huge tree and placed it on wheels. It rumbles ominously TOWARD CAMERA...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: IC CONTINUES as more people join the swell of those leaving York.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: keeps coming on.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INSIDE THE WALLS OF THE CITY

direction.raw_text: The governor is furious and confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Governor turns to his captain with a look worthy of his uncle, Longshanks the King.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We will not allow a bandit to panic the greatest city in Northern England! Close off the escapes! Let no one leave!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The city has emptied already, Sire. Only the Scottish civilians remain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as it picks up speed and SLAMS into the wooden gate of the city. With the collision, THE BATTLE IS ON. It's a night battle: torches, flaming arrows, pots of boiling oil being splashed down at the attackers, who swarm the gate. The oil beats the first wave of Scots back, but Wallace rushes forward, grabbing the ram cart with his own hands; the attackers rally to him, helping him slam the gate again and again. It breaks; but behind it is an awful tangle of carts, broken sheds, impenetrable rubbish. Wallace grabs a torch, throws it into the wooden tangle, and shouts -- WALLACE Back! Wait for it to burn!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Captain hurries into the tower room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They've breached the wall!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then do as I ordered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Scots wait, biding their time as the barrier burns. Suddenly they look up in horror; the English are throwing the bodies of hanged Scots over the wall. They stare at this in mute shock. Wallace is frozen, his eyes reflecting his boyhood reaction. His men rush forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Scots look at the hanging bodies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace draws his broadsword. The burning debris inside the gate collapses, leaving a tunnel through the fire. Wallace screams, and leads the charge through the burning barrier.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ! NOT YET! LISTEN TO ME! (beat) They wish to frighten us! Or goad us into attacking too soon! Don't look away! LOOK!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Behold the enemy we fight! We will be more merciful than they have been. We will spare women, children, and priests. For all else, no mercy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Prince Edward and Phillip, his fencing friend and lover, hear a contingent of horsemen clatter into the courtyard below; they look out the window and see the arrival of Longshanks. They lean back into the room and Edward begins to pace nervously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward shows Phillip the dagger he has concealed in his belt behind his back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Longshanks bangs the door open and stalks in angrily. First he glares at Phillip with obvious loathing, then turns his piercing stare to his own son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A messenger enters and hands the prince a message. Edward reads it and nearly loses his balance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The messenger has also brought a basket. He approaches the central table with great dread and places the basket on it, uncovering its contents. Prince Edward is closest; he looks in, then staggers back, stunned. Longshanks moves to the sack coldly, looks in, and withdraws the severed head of his nephew, York's (former) Governor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The king drops the head back into the sack, unmoved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Longshanks nods as if impressed. He moves to Phillip and examines the gold chain of office that the young man wears. Then Longshanks grabs him and throws him out the window, the same one Edward and Phillip were looking out, six stories above the courtyard. We hear Phillip's SCREAM as he falls. Edward rushes toward the window in horror. He looks out at the result, turns back toward his father in shock and hatred, and only then remembers the dagger and goes for it. He stabs at Longshanks; the old king smiles at the attack, parrying, letting his arms be cut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then Longshanks unleashes his own hateful fury; he grapples with Edward, knocking the dagger away and hurling him to the floor; then Longshanks kicks his son, again and again. He exhausts his fury on him. Edward is a bloody mess; Longshanks coughs up a bit of blood. He ignores it and his son's wreckage, and goes back to the discussion, as if this fight was normal business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Longshanks calculates.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It is not your fault! Stand up to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will stand up to him, and more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What news of the north?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing new, Majesty. We have sent riders to speed any word.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: While I am in France fighting to expand your future kingdom I learn that Stirling castle is lost, our entire northern army wiped out! And you have done nothing?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have ordered conscriptions...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wallace has sacked York!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Impossible. (to messenger) How dare you bring a panicky lie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sire! Thy own nephew! What beast could do such a thing?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If he can sack York, he can invade lower England.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We would stop him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Edward, who is this shitpoker who speaks to me as if I needed his advice?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have declared Phillip my High Counselor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You fight back at last!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We must sue for a truce, and buy him off. But who will go to him? Not I. If I came under the sword of this murderer, I would end up like my nephew. And not you, the sight of my faggot son would only encourage an enemy to take over this country. So whom do I send?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A full encampment, across an English field; campfires chase the dawn chill. Soldiers sharpen swords and spear points. Wallace is huddled with his inner circle, all except Campbell, who receives a report from a scout.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace buckles on his sword.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A royal entourage comes, flying banners of truce, and the standards of Longshanks himself!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - YORKSHIRE - DAY Set up for a meeting in a sunny meadow. Wallace and his men ride in, wary, ready for ambush. They surround the tent. There are two dozen royal soldiers there, but they make no threatening moves. No sound from the tent. Wallace rests his hand on the handle of his broadsword, ready.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Servants pull back the sides of the tent door, and a tall, slender, shapely female figure appears there. There in the shadows, she looks just like Marion! William is not the only one who notices the resemblance; he glances at Hamish and Campbell and sees them haunted by it too. Is this another dream? He pales, as she steps into the morning sun. She moves toward him, her face lowered. It is Marion! She reaches him, lifts her face... and he sees the Princess! William is relieved -- and yet as he sees the Princess more closely he is still shaken by the resemblance in the way she carries herself, her shape, the fall of her hair. The Princess is struck with Wallace, too -- tall, powerful, and commanding. Wallace dismounts, and moves to face her. Their eyes hang on each other. She sees something that she has not seen in the face of a man in her whole life. She surprises him by bending at the knee, in a half-submissive yet proud curtsey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods; somehow she is already ashamed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She leads him under the pavilion, a purple canopy shading rich carpets laid on the bare ground. Watching the gorgeous walk, Stephen lies back on his saddle and twitches his leg like a horny dog. Hamish backhands him; Campbell, Hamish and Stephen quickly dismount and follow the procession, shouldering their way in beside the Princess's French guards, so they can watch Wallace's back. The rest of the Scots surround the tent, ready for ambush. Nicolette is among the royal attendants there; seeing Wallace, she shoots a glance at the Princess that says Ooo-La-La! The servants have brought a throne for the Princess, a lower chair for Wallace. She sits; he refuses the chair. She studies him, taking in his anger and his pride.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But knowing Longshanks' family, she glances at a richly dressed Advisor, a CRONY of the king, who averts his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Crony mumbles to her in LATIN, WITH SUBTITLES...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are startled at Wallace's fluency in Latin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stares for a long moment at Wallace's eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reluctantly obeys. Seeing that she wants the exchange to be private, Wallace turns and nods for his men to leave. Stephen, who has been admiring the lady's beauty non-stop, leans in and whispers to William...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stephen moves off with Hamish and Campbell. Wallace and the princess are left alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The outburst startles even those watching from a distance. The Princess is mesmerized by Wallace's passion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Princess is stunned; Wallace is dead still.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Princess rises slowly from her chair, moves in front of him, and lowers herself to her knees. The Crony and her other attendants, seeing this from a distance, are shocked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She lifts her face. Their eyes hold a moment too long.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Longshanks! I have come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am the Princess of Wales.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wife of Edward, the king's son?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I come as the king's servant, and with his authority.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's battle I want, not talk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But now that I am here, will you speak with a woman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I understand that you have recently been given the rank of knight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have been given nothing. God makes men what they are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did God make you the sacker of peaceful cities? The executioner of the king's nephew, my husband's own cousin?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: York was the staging point for every invasion of my country. And that royal cousin hanged a hundred Scots, even women and children, from the city walls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That is not possible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Longshanks did far worse, the last time he took a Scottish city.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Latin) He is a murdering bandit, he lies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Latin!) I am no bandit. And I do not lie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or in French if you prefer that: Certainmous et ver! Ask your king to his face, and see if his eyes can convince you of the truth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hamilton, leave us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: M'lady -- PRINCESS Leave us now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Her husband's more of a queen than she is. Did you know that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let us talk plainly. You invade England. But you cannot complete the conquest, so far from your shelter and supply. The King proposes that you withdraw your attack. In return he grants you title, estates, and this chest with a thousand pounds of gold, which I am to pay to you personally.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lordship. And gold. That I should become Judas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Peace is made is such ways.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: WALLACE SLAVES ARE MADE IN SUCH WAYS

dialogue.raw_text: I understand you have suffered. I know... about your woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She was my wife. We married in secret because I would not share her with an English lord. They killed her to get to me. And she was pregnant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've never told anyone. I don't know why I tell you -- except because you look... much like her. And someday you will be a queen, and you must open your eyes! (beat) Tell your king that William Wallace will not be ruled. Nor will any Scot, while I live.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir. I leave this money, as a gift. Not from the king, but from myself. And not to you, but to the orphans of your country.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . FIELD - DAY Wallace and his captains sit on horseback at the head of their company and watch as the Princess' procession leaves. Hamish studies Wallace's face; Wallace notices and gives him a non-committal shrug. As the carriage rolls away, its window curtains lift back slightly. All they see are the Princess' fingers, but they know she looked back. Wallace reins his horse away, to ride back to camp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The doors open; the Princess enters Longshanks' war council; Prince Edward is there, among a dozen others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She barely curtseys, and starts out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He already knows she didn't; Hamilton is standing near him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From a box at his feet the king withdraws a crossbow and throws it onto the table. Most of those there are shocked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Longshanks smiles. No one notices that the Princess is deadly pale.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: My son's loyal wife returns, unkilled by the heathen. So he accepted our bribe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. He did not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why does he stay? My scouts say he has not advanced.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He waits. For you. He says he will attack no more towns -- if you are man enough to come fight him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You spoke with this Wallace in private. What kind of man is he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...A mindless barbarian. Not a king like you, M'lord.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Scottish nobles have sent him no support. His army starves. Our stall has worked, he must withdraw. You may return to your embroidery.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Humbly, M'lord.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You brought back the money, of course?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I have it to ease the suffering of the children of this war.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (glances at son) This is what happens when you must send a woman. And a fool.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forgive me, Sire. I thought that generosity might demonstrate your greatness to those you mean to rule.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My greatness is better demonstrated with this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The weapon has been outlawed by the Pope himself!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So the Scots will have none of them, will they? My armorers have already made a thousand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Scots are lining up to leave their encampment. Wallace is about to give the signal to start the march when Hamish, beside him, comes alert; a small group of riders in distinctive attire are coming toward them; what can this be?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The riders stop at a distance, and out from their ranks comes a single rider, sitting sidesaddle. It is Nicolette. Wallace and Hamish recognize her from the Princess's visit. She trots her horse the rest of the way, while the French guards stay back. Hamish helps her from her horse. She moves to Wallace, and opens the heavy folds of her heavy riding cape. Secreted there, hung from a rope at her neck, is a crossbow.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: William -- French guards?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Wallace has gathered the nobles, among them Robert the Bruce, Mornay, and old Craig, for a demonstration. Hamish and Stephen have placed a spearman's chestplate against a bale of hay. As William cranks the crossbow to its full cocked position and places a bolt in its slot, Stephen tucks a melon behind the armor. William aims... and fires. The bolt slashes through the air and punches through the armor and the melon, leaving no doubt what it would do to a man's heart. The nobles pale.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Bruce sees Wallace about to explode, and tries to intervene -- but Wallace's anger is too great.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The nobles grip their weapons; Wallace, Hamish and Stephen are ready to finish this quarrel right here. Robert the Bruce, backed by Mornay, steps between the two sides.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The nobles stalk away, and Robert draws Wallace away, to the target Wallace shot, so they are alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The question strikes deep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Robert the Bruce walks off the field, heading the way the other nobles went. Wallace rejoins Hamish and Stephen. They look to him; what do we do now?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That is why the Pope outlawed the weapon! It makes war too terrible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How many does Longshanks have?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A thousand. (beat) You have made me Guardian of Scotland. So I tell you this is what we face.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We must sue for peace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Peace?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We cannot defeat this -- WALLACE With cavalry -- not heavy, like the English, but light, fast horsemen, like you nobles employ -- we could outmaneuver their bowmen!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is suicide.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir William --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We won at Stirling and still you quibbled! We won at York and you would not support us! Then I said nothing! Now I say you are cowards!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, Sir William! Speak with me alone! I beg you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have achieved more than anyone dreamed. But fighting these odds looks like rage, not courage. Peace offers its rewards! Has war become a habit you cannot break?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: War finds me willing. I know it won't bring back all I have lost. But it can bring what none of us have ever had -- a country of our own. For that we need a king. We need you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am trying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then tell me what a king is! Is he a man who believes only what others believe? Is he one who calculates the numbers for and against him but never weighs the strength in your own heart? There is strength in you. I see it. I know it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I must... consult with my father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I will consult with mine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Remember when the English turned their hounds on us? Maybe we should introduce them to our dogs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: INT.
location: THE DARKENED ROOM OF BRUCE THE ELDER, THE LEPER

direction.raw_text: In the faint nimbus of the single candle, young Robert sits across from his leper father. The son grips his own head, as if stunned by a blow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heartsick, the father reaches across the table, then stays his arm, unwilling to touch his son with his leprous hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Young Robert holds his father with his eyes, and does not look away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This... cannot be the way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have said yourself that the nobles will not support Wallace, so how does it help us to join the side that is slaughtered?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My son. Look at me. I cannot be king. You, and you alone, can rule Scotland. What I tell you, you must do -- for yourself, and for your country.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Scottish army moves out onto the hilly plain, covered in the gray mists. They see glimpses of the enemy in the distance. Wallace deploys the Scots: Campbell with the schiltrons (spear formations), Stephen with the infantry, the noble Mornay leading the cavalry, and with Wallace and Hamish on horseback, looking over the field. Hamish sees gazing up at an empty hill above the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'd better, the odds look long. And it's nasty ground; one side of the field is ankle deep in water, and the English are covering it with a layer of burning oil, releasing thick smoke to hide their movements.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Priest from their home village is moving through the Scottish ranks, dispensing absolution. He reaches the two friends, who accept the Host, say their own last prayers, and give each other a look of goodbye. Hamish rides off to join the schiltrons.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The Bruce is not coming, William.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mornay has come. So will the Bruce.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stephen ready?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: on the opposite side of the field, send their army forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: see them through the smoke; Wallace spots what he's looking for: there they are, the ranks of crossbowmen! And as they draw nearer, Wallace hears a haunting noise. He sees the bowmen more clearly, and the English infantry. Some are wearing kilts and marching to bagpipes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Irish troops!
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: STEPHEN OF IRELAND, WITH THE SCOTTISH INFANTRY

direction.raw_text: He stares at the approach of his countrymen. Wallace appears beside him. Stephen sees him, and is ashamed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Loyal to the end. Wallace signals to Hamish and Campbell, among the schiltrons. The formations, bristling with spears, move forward. Hamish looks back at Wallace; both men know the spearmen are the bait here. Wallace and Stephen see the English heavy cavalry advancing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace is scanning the battlefield. He sees the English cavalry charge, but before they reach the bristling spears, they pull up, and crossbowmen, moving up behind the knights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The crossbowmen fire a volley, too hurriedly. We see the hailstorm of bolts slash through the air in unison -- you can actually see them coming. The bows fall short of the front ranks of the schiltrons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stephen signals, and up the slope behind them come handlers with ten war dogs. Huge mastiffs, they wear steel collars, with razor sharp protrusions. Their handlers hold them at the end of long catch poles. The crossbowmen are distracted from their reloading by the appearance of the mastiffs; now, as the Scottish handlers run toward the English ranks and unleash the dogs, fear races through the English line. The dogs tear into them. It is chaos; the bowmen can't flee, and as the dogs mix among them, the bowmen fire frantically, mostly hitting each other. The dogs' collars slash legs; their jaws crush bones; even when their back legs are hacked off, the frenzied dogs keep killing. Wallace signals to Mornay with the Scottish cavalry. Mornay does nothing. The crossbowmen, though taking great punishment, are beginning to overwhelm the dogs by sheer numbers, and are regrouping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mornay tugs his reins and leads his cavalry away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So that's where Longshanks got his soldiers. Irishmen, willing to kill Scottish cousins for the English.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Their families are starving, they'll feed them however they can. If you don't want to fight them -- STEPHEN No. I'll stand with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They can't be that stupid to attack the schiltrons again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's only a faint to shield the crossbows!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now! Give 'em the dogs!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now! Charge! Charge them!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Longshanks and his officers see Mornay and his cavalry melt away. The English general looks knowingly at Longshanks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mornay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For double his lands in Scotland, and matching estates in England.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They see the Scottish army abandoned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace glances to the other hilltop; still no sign of Bruce. He looks on in agony as the crossbowmen unleash another volley. The Scottish spearmen, bunched in a tight group, are helpless. The bolts fall, cutting through their helmets and breastplates like paper. Wallace has no cavalry -- and his men are being slaughtered! He spurs his horse, and Stephen and the infantrymen race behind him. The English heavy cavalry surge to meet them, but Wallace weaves through them, dodging with his horse, slashing with the broadsword, cutting down on knight, another, another... The Scottish infantry claws in, dragging down the horses, hacking the knights as they run by. The English bowmen are about to fire again, but they see the Scottish charge bearing down on them and adjust their aim; the bolts cut into the infantrymen; one bolt tears off the armor of Wallace's left shoulder. He wobbles on his horse, regains his balance, and keeps up the charge.

direction.raw_text: On horseback, Wallace fights his way into the watery edge of the field, where English infantry is now overrunning the schiltron. He hacks men down left and right, reaches the Scottish center, and finds Hamish bending over another soldier. Wallace dismounts.

direction.raw_text: The Scots pull up spears and hastily form another schiltron. The spears bristle out, ready... the English horsemen thunder in. But before the spears impale the horses, another flight of crossbow bolts cuts down half the Scots still fighting. Hamish reaches the rear of the battle and lowers the limp body of his father to the Scottish monks who are attending to the wounded and giving absolution to the dying... Still Wallace fights back, meeting the English charge. The Scots hold their own. An English knight tries to ride over William; he knocks the lance aside, and tough the horse slams into him, William also unseats the rider. The rider rolls to his feet. William struggles up to meet him -- and comes face to face with Robert the Bruce. The shock and recognition stun Wallace; in that moment, looking at Robert the Bruce's guilt-ridden face, he understands everything: the betrayal, the hopelessness of Scotland. As he stands there frozen, a bolt punches into the muscle of his neck, and Wallace doesn't react to it. Bruce is horrified at the sight of Wallace this way. He batters at Wallace's sword, as if its use would give him absolution.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Wallace can only stagger back. Bruce's voice grows ragged as he screams.

direction.raw_text: All around, the battle has decayed; the Scots are being slaughtered. Another bolt glances off Wallace's helmet; a third rips into his thigh plate, making his legs collapse. Suddenly Stephen comes through the melee, on Robert's horse! He hits Robert from behind, knocking him down, and jumps to the ground to try and lift William onto the horse! Robert sees a knot of crossbowmen moving up, sighting out Wallace, taking careful aim! Bruce leaps up and helps Stephen sling Wallace onto the back of the horse, even covers him with his shield, deflecting another bolt fired at Wallace, as Stephen mounts too. As the horse plunges away into the smoke, Robert falls to the water. His own troops reach him, realize who he is, see the horrible expression on his face, and race on after the Scots. Robert is left alone, on his knees in the water, the fire and noise of battle now dim to him, as if his senses have died along with his heart.

He stares at Robert the Bruce, who averts his eyes. The soldiers hurry Wallace out the back, where others are bringing up horses. Robert grabs the English Captain of the soldiers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Captain looks at Bruce the way the High Priest must have looked at Judas, and leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Robert the Bruce spots something on the floor that must have fallen from Wallace's clothes as they grabbed him; Bruce lifts the white handkerchief, and sees the familiar thistle embroidered on it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He is not to be harmed. I have your king's absolute promise that he will be imprisoned only!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now we will have peace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A procession of heavily armed English soldiers winds its way toward London, Wallace strapped to an unsaddled horse, his head bare to the sun. Country people come out to jeer...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A thrown rock careens off Wallace's check; rotten fruit slaps his shirt. His lips are so parched they bleed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't look so fearsome, does he?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edward inspects his father, who lies semiconscious in bed, breath rattling ominously in his chest. Edward approves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Princess hurries up to her husband as he leaves the king's bedroom, and follows him down the hall to his own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a faint smile, he shuts his bedroom door in her face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Is it true? Wallace is captured?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Simply because he eluded your trap, do you think he is more than a man? My father is dying. Perhaps you should think of our coronation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When will his trial be?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wallace's? For treason there is no trial. Tomorrow he will be charged, then executed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Bruce is incredulous, yelling at Craig.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Longshanks promised!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are surprised he would lie? Balliol was murdered in a church yesterday. You are Longshanks' new designate. You will be king.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Wallace stands in medieval restraints worthy of Hannibal Lecter. Before him are six scarlet-robed royal magistrates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We PUSH IN on the iron mask that binds his face. We can only see his eyes -- but they are bright.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: William Wallace! You stand in taint of high treason.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Treason. Against whom?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Against thy king, thou vile fool! Hast thou anything to say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never, in my whole life, did I swear allegiance to your king -- MAGISTRATE It matters not, he is thy king!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: while many who serve him have taken and broken his oath many times. I cannot commit treason, if I have never been his subject!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Confess, and you may receive a quick death. Deny, and you must be purified by pain. Do you confess? ...DO YOU CONFESS?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do not confess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then on the morrow, thou shalt receive they purification... And in the end, I promise you'll beg for the axe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ESTABLISHING - THE TOWER The stone prison, and the wretched stone section known to this day as the Wallace Tower.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace is alone in his cell, still in the garish restraints. We can only see his eyes, as he prays.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I am so afraid... Give me strength.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The jailers jump to their feet as the Princess enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The jailer obeys. The Princess can barely contain her shock at the sight of Wallace; the jailers snatch him upright.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reluctantly the jailers shuffle out of the cell, but they can still see her back and hear her. Looking at Wallace's eyes through the mask, she can't quite hold back her tears -- dangerous tears, that threaten to say too much. Wallace tries to distract her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She wants to plead, she wants to scream. She can't stop the tears. And the jailers are watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She almost goes too far now, pulling closer to him -- but she doesn't care. She whispers, pleading...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She pulls out a hidden vial, and whispers...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the verge of hysteria, she presses the vial to the air hole at his mouth and pours in the drug. The jailers, seeing suspicious movement, shift inside the cell; she backs up, her eyes wide, full of love and goodbye. From inside the mask, he watches her go. When the door CLANGS shut, he spits the purple drug out through the mouth hole.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Your Highness!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will see the prisoner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've orders from the king -- PRINCESS The king will be dead in a month! And his son is a weakling! Who do you think will rule this kingdom? Now OPEN THIS DOOR!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On your feet, you filth!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop! Leave me! (they hesitate) There is no way out of this hell! Leave me with him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: M'lady... what kindness of you to visit a stranger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, I... come to beg you to confess all, and swear allegiance to the king, that he might show you mercy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will he show mercy to my country? Will he take back his soldiers, and let us rule ourselves?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mercy... is to die quickly. Perhaps even live in the Tower. In time, who knows what can happen, if you can only live.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I swear to him, then everything I am is dead already.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your people are lucky to have a princess so kind that she can grieve at the death of a stranger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You will die! It will be awful!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Every man dies. Not every man really lives.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Drink this! It will dull your pain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It will numb my wits, and I must have them all. If I'm senseless, or if I wail, then Longshanks will have broken me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't bear the thought of your torture. Take it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Longshanks lies helpless, his body racked with consumption. Edward sits against the wall, watching him die, glee in his eyes. The Princess enters, and marches to the bedside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Longshanks shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The king can't speak. But hatred still glows in his eyes. The princess looks at her husband.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She leans down and grabs the dying king by the hair. The guards flanking the door start forward but the Princess's eyes flare at them with more fire than even Longshanks once showed -- and the guards back off. She leans down and hisses to Longshanks, so softly that even Edward can't hear...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She lets go of the old king. He sags like an empty sack back onto his satin pillows. Without even a look at her husband she strides out of the room, with the rattling breath of the dying king rasping the air like a saw.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I have come to beg for the life of William Wallace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You fancy him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I respect him. At worst he was a worthy enemy. Show mercy... Oh thou great king... and win the respect of your own people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even now, you are incapable of mercy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nor you. To you that word is as unfamiliar as love.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Before he lost his powers of speech, he told me his one comfort was that he would live to know Wallace was dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see? Death comes to us all. And it comes to William Wallace. But before death comes to you, know this: your blood dies with you. A child who is not of your line grows in my belly. Your son will not sit long on the throne. I swear it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The crowd is festive; hawkers sell roast chickens, and beer from barrels. Royal horsemen arrive, dragging Wallace strapped to a wooden litter. As they cut him loose and lead him through the crowd, the people begin to jeer and throw things at him: chicken bones, rocks, empty tankards. We see a former English soldier, one of those who fled in terror at the battle of Stirling, lift a stone from the street and hurl it; it cracks against Wallace's cheek. Wallace's eyes capture the soldier, and hold him, piercing his soul. The soldier looks away in shame, even as the rest of the crowd jeers more. Grim magistrates prod Wallace and he climbs the execution platform. On the platform are a noose, a dissection table with knives in plain view, and a chopping block with an enormous axe. Wallace sees it all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He emphasizes "mercy" by pointing to the axe. Wallace is pale, and trebles -- but he shakes his head. The CROWD grows noisier as they put the noose around Wallace's neck...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We will use it all before this is over. Or fall to your knees now, declare yourself the king's loyal subject, and beg his mercy, and you shall have it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: in helpless agony, hearing the DISTANT NOISE from her room in the palace...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hamish and Stephen, disguised as peasants among the crowd, helpless too, but there, as if to shoulder some of the pain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Longshanks, rattling, coughing blood, as Edward watches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Robert the Bruce paces along the walls of his castle in Scotland. His eyes are haunted; he grips the embroidered handkerchief that belonged to Wallace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a trio of burly hooded executioners cinch a rope around Wallace's neck and hoist him up a pole.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the SCORE, AMAZING GRACE, wailed on bagpipes, carries through all that happens now... Ties hand and foot, Wallace is strangling. The Magistrate watches coldly; even when the executioner gives him a look that says they're about to go too far, he prolongs the moment; then the Magistrate nods and the executioner cuts the rope. Wallace slams to the platform; the Magistrate leans to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With great effort, Wallace rises to his knees. The Magistrate assumes a formal posture and offers the cloak. Wallace struggles all the way to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The executioners slam Wallace onto his back on the table, spread his arms and legs, and tie each to a crank. Goaded by the crowd, they pull the ropes taut. They crowd grows quiet enough to hear the groaning of Wallace's limbs. Hamish and Stephen feel it in their own bodies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace shakes his head. The executioners cut off his clothes, take hot irons from a fire box. The crowd grows silent; we see them, not Wallace, as the irons are touched to his body, but we hear the burning of flesh. Then the Magistrate signals; Wallace wants to say something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone hears; Hamish smiles, even through his tears. Rebuffed, the Magistrate nods to the executioners, who lift the terrible instruments of dissection. We are spared seeing the cutting: we are ON WALLACE'S FACE as the disembowelment begins. The Magistrate leans in beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The crowd can't hear the magistrate but they know the procedure, and they goad Wallace, chanting...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace's eyes roll to the magistrate, who signals QUIET!
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's it! Stretch him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pleasant, yes? Rise to your knees, kiss the royal emblem on my cloak, and you will feel no more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very well then. Rack him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wonderful, isn't it, that a man remains conscious through such pain. Enough?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That... will... clear your sinuses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It can all end. Right now! Bliss. Peace. Just say it. Cry out. "Mercy!" Yes?... Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mer-cy! Mer-cy! Mer-cy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (booming) The prisoner wishes to say a word!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Hamish and Stephen weep, whisper, pray...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wallace's eyes flutter, and clear. He fights through the pain, struggles for one last deep breath, and screams...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The shout RINGS through the town. Hamish hears it. The Princess hears it, at her open window, and touches her tummy, just showing the first signs of her pregnancy. Longshanks and his son seem to hear; the cry STILL ECHOES as if the wind could carry it through the ends of Scotland; and Robert the Bruce, on the walls of his castle, looks up sharply, as if he has heard...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mercy, William... Say Mercy...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the crowd has never seen courage like this; even English strangers begin to weep. The angry, defeated magistrate gives a signal. They cut the ropes, drag Wallace over and put his head on the block. The executioner lifts his huge axe -- and Wallace looks toward the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sees Hamish, eyes brimming, face glowing...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - THE AXE begins to drop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the last half-moment of his life, when he has already stepped into the world beyond this one, he glimpses someone standing at Hamish's shoulder. She is beautiful, smiling, serene. She is Marion.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: AT THE OPEN GRAVE WHERE MARION LAY,

direction.raw_text: His face has changed. He is standing AT THE OPEN GRAVE WHERE MARION LAY, the headstone carved with the thistle still there. He holds the handkerchief. As he tucks it into his own pocket, and we MOVE IN on his eyes, we realize the VOICE OVER belongs to him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) After the beheading, William Wallace's body was torn to pieces. His head was set on London bridge, where passerby were invited to jeer at the man who had caused so much fear in England. (beat) His arms and legs were sent to the four corners of Britain as warning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see the people, as the remains of William Wallace are displayed in a box. The faces of the young men are fiery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More young men put on tartans, take up their weapons, and gather into fighting units. Among them is Hamish, carrying a shield emblazoned with a cocked arm holding a broadsword, and the words "For Freedom."
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) It did not have the effect that Longshanks planned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Robert the Bruce, flanked by the noblemen and the banners of the Scottish throne, and backed by a ragtag army of Scots, sits on his horse and looks down at the English generals in their martial finery. The English are haughty, victorious, at the head of their colorful, polished army, awaiting the ceremony of submission from Scotland's new king.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) And I, Robert the Bruce, backed by a body of Scottish veterans, rode out to pay homage to the armies of the English king, and accept his endorsement of my crown.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: FROM BELOW, ON THE OPEN PLAIN

direction.raw_text: The Scots -- the remains of William Wallace's army -- look so ragged and defeated that it hardly seems worth the wait. One ENGLISH COMMANDER turns and jokes with another...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I hope you washed your ass this mornin -- it's never been kissed by a king before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Robert the Bruce sits on his horse, and waits. He looks down at the English generals, at their banners, their army. He looks down the ranks at his own. He sees Hamish. Stephen. Old MacClannough is there, his eyes watery, his weapon sharp. The Scottish bride Lord Bottoms took is there, among the ragtag archers, her husband beside her. Robert knows none of them -- yet he knows them all. Old Craig, among the other Scottish nobles mounted beside the Bruce, grows impatient.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Robert holds something -- uncurling his fist, he looks at the thistle handkerchief that belonged to Wallace. The nobles start to rein their horses toward the English.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Robert the Bruce tucks the handkerchief safely behind his breastplate, and turns to the Highlanders who line the hilltop with him. He takes a long breath, and shouts -- ROBERT THE BRUCE You have bled with Wallace! Now bleed with me! Bruce's broadsword slides from its scabbard. A cry rises from Highlanders, as from a tomb, rising -- SCOTS Wal-lace! Wal-lace! Wal-lace! The chant builds to a frenzy; it shakes the earth. The Scottish nobles can scarcely believe it; the English are shocked even more. Robert the Bruce, king of Scotland, spurs his horse into full gallop toward the English, and the Highlanders hurl their bodies down the hill, ready to run through hell itself. In SLOW MOTION we see their faces... And OVER THIS, we hear the voice of William Wallace...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On Wallace's army behind Robert the Bruce, charging down the hill to victory and glory, we slow to FREEZE FRAME and hear their chant, huge, echoing...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come, let's get it over with.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In the year of our Lord 1314, patriots of Scotland, starving and outnumbered, charged the fields of Bannockburn. They fought like warrior poets. They fought like Scotsmen. And won their freedom. Forever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wal-lace! Wal-lace! Wal-lace!
dialogue.name: dialogue
